title: link_to with "turbo_method: :delete" triggers DELETE request for consecutive redirect (instead of GET)
body:
In a nested resource scenario this might lead to unwanted deletion of the "parent" resource with all its dependent resources when only a dependent resource was meant to be deleted. E.g. for articles with comments, deleting a comment might cause the deletion of the relevant article (and all its other comments). ### Steps to reproduce I worked through the example in the [Getting Started guide](https://guides.rubyonrails.org/getting_started.html#deleting-comments), and stumbled over a somewhat surprising behavior when deleting a comment from an article. Relevant code in `app/views/articles/show.html.erb`: ```ruby
  • <%= link_to "Destroy", article_path(@article), data: { turbo_method: :delete, turbo_confirm: "Are you sure?" } %>
    • ``` Relevant code in `app/controllers/comments_controller.rb`: ```ruby def destroy @article = Article.find(params[:article_id]) @comment = @article.comments.find(params[:id]) @comment.destroy redirect_to article_path(@article), status: :see_other # or: status: 303 end ``` At some time I omitted the explicitly given `status` option, using the following line: ``` ruby redirect_to article_path(@article) ``` Similar to other occurrences of `redirect_to` without `status` in the code examples of the Getting Started guide. ### Expected behavior After clicking on "Destroy" the comment should be deleted and the article page should be displayed (regardless of the given status). ### Actual behavior Without the `status` option, the `redirect_to` triggers a DELETE request for the article instead of a GET request, thereby also **deleting the article and all its other comments** (when `has_many :comments, dependent: :destroy` is specified in the Article model), instead of only deleting the intended comment. See also the relevant lines from the log further below. I must note that I have not much experience with Rails, and know absolutely nothing about the `turbo-` stuff, but it seems to me this is a **serious problem**. If I am mistaken, then at least the guide should clearly state the **crucial importance** of using the `status: :see_other` option with the redirect in this case. Excerpt from the log: ``` Started DELETE "/articles/10/comments/18" for ::1 at 2022-06-07 [...] Processing by CommentsController#destroy as TURBO_STREAM [...] Redirected to http://localhost:3000/articles/10 Completed 302 Found in 23ms (ActiveRecord: 10.6ms | Allocations: 3850) Started DELETE "/articles/10" for ::1 at 2022-06-07 [...] Processing by ArticlesController#destroy as TURBO_STREAM ``` ### System configuration **Rails version**: Rails 7.0.3 **Ruby version**: ruby 3.1.2p20 (2022-04-12 revision 4491bb740a) [x86_64-linux]

title: Should ActiveRecord::Relation#null_relation? be made public?
body:
I will admit this is a bit of a niche use-case, but there is currently (to my knowledge, at least) no _public_ way to determine if a relation is `none?` without executing it in the case that it is not a null relation. The protected method `null_relation?` does the right thing, but it's protected, so one must use a refinement to change its visibility. You could alternatively do `.is_a?(ActiveRecord::NullRelation)` but that seems worse.

My specific use case is that I have a scope which will short-circuit by returning `none` when the argument to that scope doesn't exist in a look-up table. I don't want to expose the details of this look-up table to callers because there are multiple callers and I don't want to repeat myself.

This scope is used in a subquery, and if the scope is `none?` we can avoid running that outer query as well. The outer query is pretty complex and involves another few queries and some joins, and it will return zero rows if the inner query is `none?`. There are also a few of these outer queries.

What we landed on is to create a refinement that implements the existing `null_relation?` method:

```ruby
      def null_relation?
        is_a?(ActiveRecord::NullRelation)
      end
```

...and then we short-circuit the outer query by going `return none if subquery_scope.null_relation?`. This works exactly the same as `return none if subquery_scope.none?`, except that it doesn't execute the query when it is something.

The simplest way to make this advanced usage work is to make the protected method public, but this might confuse new users who don't know what the difference is between `none?` and `null_relation?`. I don't like the idea of doing the `is_a?` check every time (because then `NullRelation` leaks into our code in more than one place). I also think that doing something like `none?(execute: false)` is potentially surprising (it returns false when it may actually still be false if you called `.none?`), but this might be a good enough compromise in the API if others feel that `null_relation?` is potentially confusing to new users.

I did some searching and I didn't see any discussion on whether this should be public or not in the context of more modern versions of Rails. It seems like when this was introduced, it was a performance optimization primarily, and that's why the method was made protected, but that's about all I came across. I'm curious what others' thoughts are about this today.

title: Rails.cache uses 6.1 coder when 7.0 configuration defaults are loaded
body:
Sorry I am not providing a script below - wasn't sure how to best illustrate the issue in a test given the lack of public APIs here.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Set `config.cache_store = :file_store, 'tmp/cache'` in environment file (eg. `config/environments/development.rb`)
2. Load `bin/rails console` in 7.0.x Rails application
3. Note that `Rails.cache.instance_variable_get(:@coder)` returns `ActiveSupport::Cache::Coders::Rails61Coder`
4. Note that `Rails.cache.class.new('tmp/cache').instance_variable_get(:@coder)` returns `ActiveSupport::Cache::Coders::Rails70Coder`

The problem seems to be that `Rails.cache` is initialized before the app configuration is loaded. The default coder is 
[hardcoded to 6.1](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/3872bc0e54d32e8bf3a6299b0bfe173d94b072fc/activesupport/lib/active_support/cache.rb#L38) but is overridden when the [app configuration is loaded](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/ad409d5c3a7dbc1c16b5583d7fa9248099bf5360/railties/lib/rails/application/configuration.rb#L228).

This can be worked around by manually setting `ActiveSupport::Cache.format_version = 7.0` before the app is initialized, or by re-initializing `Rails.cache` after the app configuration is loaded.

[The configuration docs](https://guides.rubyonrails.org/configuring.html#config-active-support-cache-format-version) seemed to indicate no special handling would be needed to use the 7.0 serializer. 

### Expected behavior

When `application.rb` uses `load_defaults 7.0` and doesn't override the `cache_format_version`, `Rails.cache` should use the 7.0 cache coder.

### Actual behavior

When `application.rb` uses `load_defaults 7.0` and doesn't override the `cache_format_version`, `Rails.cache` use the 6.1 cache coder by default.

### System configuration

I've seen this using `FileStore` and `NullStore`, but have not looked at the behavior of the other cache store types.

**Rails version**: 
7.0.3

**Ruby version**: 
3.0.4

from the original source code: ```ruby class MyWorker include Sidekiq::Worker def perform MyModel.where('x < ?', 1.month.ago).where(a_column: A_VALUE).find_each do |my_model| something # ... end end ``` This has been reported before [here](https://github.com/rails/rails/issues/40608) but without a specific solution. `sentry-raven`, `sentry-ruby` and `activerecord-import` title: Enumerable::index_with will share the memory of the default value between keys
body:
### Steps to reproduce
Apologies if I'm misunderstanding the method, but AFAIK each default value should be independent.

So far as I've tested, arrays and hashes. Those are being shared. However if the value is a string, this one will not be shared.

<!-- (Guidelines for creating a bug report are [available
here](https://edgeguides.rubyonrails.org/contributing_to_ruby_on_rails.html#creating-a-bug-report)) -->

<!-- Paste your executable test case created from one of the scripts found [here](https://edgeguides.rubyonrails.org/contributing_to_ruby_on_rails.html#create-an-executable-test-case) below: -->

This will fail:

```ruby
# frozen_string_literal: true

require "bundler/inline"

gemfile(true) do
  source "https://rubygems.org"

  git_source(:github) { |repo| "https://github.com/#{repo}.git" }

  gem "rails", github: "rails/rails", branch: "main"
end

require "active_support"
require "active_support/core_ext/enumerable"
require "minitest/autorun"

class BugTest < Minitest::Test
  def test_index_with_shared_memory
    keys = [:only_i_should_change, :i_should_stay_empty]
    subject = keys.index_with({})

    subject[:only_i_should_change][:a_key] = "value"

    assert subject[:only_i_should_change][:a_key] == "value"
    assert subject[:i_should_stay_empty] == {}
  end
end
```

This will succeed however.

```ruby
# frozen_string_literal: true

require "bundler/inline"

gemfile(true) do
  source "https://rubygems.org"

  git_source(:github) { |repo| "https://github.com/#{repo}.git" }

  gem "rails", github: "rails/rails", branch: "main"
end

require "active_support"
require "active_support/core_ext/enumerable"
require "minitest/autorun"

class BugTest < Minitest::Test
  def test_index_with_shared_memory
    keys = [:only_i_should_change, :i_should_stay_empty]
    subject = keys.index_with("a_string")

    subject[:only_i_should_change] = "value"

    assert subject[:only_i_should_change] == "value"
    assert subject[:i_should_stay_empty] == "a_string"
  end
end
```

### Expected behavior
When using arrays or hashes, the values should be independent. In the failed example that means that the hash under the key `:is_should_stay_empty` should be empty

### Actual behavior
When using arrays or hashes, the values are not independent. In the failed example the hash under the key `:is_should_stay_empty` is the same as `:only_i_should_change`.

### System configuration
**Rails version**:
[v7.0.3](https://github.com/rails/rails/releases/tag/v7.0.3)

**Ruby version**:
Ruby version 2.7.5

title: Regression: Filtering a timestamp with timezone by date range
body:
### Steps to reproduce
```
require "bundler/inline"

gemfile(true) do
  source "https://rubygems.org"

  git_source(:github) { |repo| "https://github.com/#{repo}.git" }

  gem "rails", github: "rails/rails", branch: "v6.1.6"
  # gem "rails", github: "rails/rails"
  gem "pg"
  gem "byebug"
end

require "active_record"
require "minitest/autorun"
require "logger"

ActiveRecord::Base.establish_connection(adapter: "postgresql", database: "bugreport")
ActiveRecord::Base.logger = Logger.new(STDOUT)
ActiveRecord::Base.time_zone_aware_attributes = true

ActiveRecord::Schema.define do
  connection.execute <<-SQL
    DROP TABLE IF EXISTS public.courses;
    CREATE TABLE public.courses (
      id bigint NOT NULL,
      start_date timestamp with time zone
    );

    CREATE SEQUENCE public.courses_id_seq
      START WITH 1
      INCREMENT BY 1
      NO MINVALUE
      NO MAXVALUE
      CACHE 1;
    ALTER SEQUENCE public.courses_id_seq OWNED BY public.courses.id;
    ALTER TABLE ONLY public.courses ALTER COLUMN id SET DEFAULT nextval('public.courses_id_seq'::regclass);
    ALTER TABLE ONLY public.courses
      ADD CONSTRAINT courses_pkey PRIMARY KEY (id);
  SQL
end

class Course < ActiveRecord::Base
end

class BugTest < Minitest::Test
  def test_matching_date_range
    Course.where(start_date: 3.days.ago.to_date..1.days.ago.to_date)
  end
end
```

This works in 6.1.6 and throws an exception in the latest rails.

title: Regression: Setting datetime inside Time#use_zone does not work
body:
### Steps to reproduce

```
# frozen_string_literal: true

require "bundler/inline"

gemfile(true) do
  source "https://rubygems.org"

  git_source(:github) { |repo| "https://github.com/#{repo}.git" }

  gem "rails", github: "rails/rails", branch: "main"
  gem "sqlite3"
end

require "active_record"
require "minitest/autorun"
require "logger"

# This connection will do for database-independent bug reports.
ActiveRecord::Base.establish_connection(adapter: "sqlite3", database: ":memory:")
ActiveRecord::Base.logger = Logger.new(STDOUT)

ActiveRecord::Schema.define do
  create_table :posts, force: true do |t|
    t.datetime :publish_after
  end
end

class Post < ActiveRecord::Base
end


class BugTest < Minitest::Test
  def test_association_stuff
    post = Post.create!
    Time.use_zone("Perth") do
      post.publish_after = '2015-03-02 09:00:00.000000000 +0000'
    end

    assert_equal "2015-03-02 09:00:00 AWST", post.publish_after.to_s
  end
end

```

### Expected behavior

The timezone specified (Perth) is used

### Actual behavior

The timezone used is UTC

### System configuration

**Rails version**:
`rails 7.1.0.alpha (was 6.1.6) from https://github.com/rails/rails.git (at main@e494efd)`


**Ruby version**:
`ruby 3.1.2p20 (2022-04-12 revision 4491bb740a) [x86_64-linux]`

title: `rails new` reports files that are not actually created
body:
### Steps to reproduce
<!-- (Guidelines for creating a bug report are [available
here](https://edgeguides.rubyonrails.org/contributing_to_ruby_on_rails.html#creating-a-bug-report)) -->

<!-- Paste your executable test case created from one of the scripts found [here](https://edgeguides.rubyonrails.org/contributing_to_ruby_on_rails.html#create-an-executable-test-case) below: -->
```ruby
rails new . --database=postgresql --no-skip-git --no-skip-keeps --no-skip-action-mailer --skip-mailbox --skip-action-text --no-skip-active-record --skip-active-job --no-skip-active-storage --skip-action-cable --skip-asset-pipeline --skip-javascript --skip-hotwire --skip-jbuilder --skip-test --skip-system-test --no-skip-bootsnap --api --skip-bundle --force --pretend
```

it prints only files that are going to be created.

### Actual behavior

body: Is there anything I am missing? Rails.cache.read() is not behaving as expected. Is there any configurations I need to do? ### Steps to reproduce ```ruby rails c Rails.cache.write("my-cache-key", 123) => true ``` ### Expected behavior ```ruby Rails.cache.read("my-cache-key") => 123 ``` ### Actual behavior ```ruby Rails.cache.read("my-cache-key") => nil ``` ### System configuration **Rails 7.0.3** **Ruby 3.0.0p0 (2020-12-25 revision 95aff21468) [x86_64-darwin20]**: ### Image

title: ActiveSupport: MessageEncryptor rotation fails to decrypt 'nil' values
body:
### Steps to reproduce
Create two instances of MessageEncryptor. The first one with only an old secret and the second one with a new secret. Add to the second one another rotation with the old secret (this is a standard scenario when rotating secrets).

The second encryptor will be able to decrypt any data encrypted with the old secret, except for `nil` values, where it will raise an exception.

#### Test case
```ruby
# frozen_string_literal: true

require "bundler/inline"

gemfile(true) do
  source "https://rubygems.org"

  gem "activesupport", "7.0.3"
end

require "active_support"
require "active_support/core_ext/object/blank"
require "minitest/autorun"

class BugTest < Minitest::Test
  def test_stuff
    old_secret = SecureRandom.base64(24)
    old_encryptor = ActiveSupport::MessageEncryptor.new old_secret

    current_secret = SecureRandom.base64(24)
    current_encryptor = ActiveSupport::MessageEncryptor.new current_secret
    current_encryptor.rotate old_secret

    # Old encryptor roundtrips a 'nil' value correctly
    assert_nil old_encryptor.decrypt_and_verify(old_encryptor.encrypt_and_sign(nil))

    # New encryptor roundtrips a 'nil' value correctly
    assert_nil current_encryptor.decrypt_and_verify(current_encryptor.encrypt_and_sign(nil))

    # Old encryptor cannot decrypt data encrypted with the current secret
    assert_raises(ActiveSupport::MessageVerifier::InvalidSignature) do
      old_encryptor.decrypt_and_verify(current_encryptor.encrypt_and_sign("test"))
    end

    # New encryptor correctly decrypts data encrypted with the old secret (being rotated)
    assert_equal "test", current_encryptor.decrypt_and_verify(old_encryptor.encrypt_and_sign("test"))

    # New encryptor should be able to decrypt a 'nil' value encrypted with the old secret --THIS FAILS--
    assert_nil current_encryptor.decrypt_and_verify(old_encryptor.encrypt_and_sign(nil))
  end
end
```

#### Possible root cause
The [method `verified`](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/3872bc0e54d32e8bf3a6299b0bfe173d94b072fc/activesupport/lib/active_support/message_verifier.rb#L152) of MessageVerifier uses the special value `nil` to signal some error conditions to the caller, but `nil` is also a valid message itself, so the [`verify` method](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/3872bc0e54d32e8bf3a6299b0bfe173d94b072fc/activesupport/lib/active_support/message_verifier.rb#L177) interprets this as a failure and raises.

### Expected behavior
A `nil` value encrypted with an old secret should be correctly decrypted as `nil` by an encryptor that has the old secret available as a rotation.

### Actual behavior
An `ActiveSupport::MessageVerifier::InvalidSignature` exception is raised.

### System configuration
**Rails version**: 7.0.3

**Ruby version**: 2.7.5

title: KeyError: Missing configuration for the s3 Active Storage service
body:
We have upgraded our rails 6 app to rails 7 and now in the process of migration paperclip to activestorage.

storage.yml 
```ruby
custom_storage:
  service: Disk
  root: <%= Rails.root.join("tmp/storage") %>
```

In development.rb
```ruby
config.active_storage.service = :custom_storage
```

model has this: 
```ruby
 has_one_attached :asset
```

When we run model_obj.asset.url it throws this error 

KeyError: Missing configuration for the s3 Active Storage service. Configurations available for the custom_storage services.

Not sure from where we get this s3 KeyError


### System configuration
**Rails version**: 7
 
**Ruby version**: 2.7.5

title: Customize Generator Docs Missing Links
body:
from: https://guides.rubyonrails.org/v7.0/generators.html#customizing-your-workflow-by-changing-generators-templates
> If you generate another resource, you can see that we get exactly the same result! This is useful if you want to customize your scaffold templates and/or layout by just creating edit.html.erb, index.html.erb and so on inside lib/templates/erb/scaffold.

I wonder why we don't have some kind of links to the [current files](https://github.com/rails/rails/tree/5257da7bb543e2b5a51da72a3e4bb77bf96eaefc/railties/lib/rails/generators/erb/scaffold/templates) here so you can easily customize based on them? I was searching for some while and just found it after searching for "display: block" in the rails repository.

title: ActiveSupport::ParameterFilter in config/initializers/**.rb cause NameError: uninitialized constant ActiveSupport::ParameterFilter in Rails7, but not cause in Rails6
body:
Excuse me. I'm sorry for your busy schedule. 
There is a problem that I just don't understand.

My rails project is using Sentry.

I am using `ActiveSupport::ParameterFilter` in `config/initializers/sentry.rb` as shown below.

https://docs.sentry.io/platforms/ruby/guides/rails/configuration/filtering/#using-platformidentifier-namebefore-send-

In my project, I'm working on updating from rails v6 to v7.
When I ran the `$ rspec`, I didn't get any error in v6, but when I updated v7, I got the following error.
(RSpec and Sentry versions are not updated.)


I know that adding `require active_support/parameter_filter` doesn't cause this errors, but I don't understand why this happens.

title: Datetime end_of_day.strftime("%Q") to return time in milliseconds just returns string "%Q"
body:
### Steps to reproduce

When type DateTime.yesterday.end_of_day.strftime("%Q") it just returns "%Q" instead of correct milliseconds
obs: period could be yesterday, tomorrow... it happens with the others periods too

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/63233782/171719559-6999f1a8-81d8-4d78-85f3-d23e0d04e4a3.png)

title: Inconsistent method signature
body:
https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/920fcce54c9e112dc724d587e58182c5603de2d0/activesupport/lib/active_support/cache/strategy/local_cache.rb#L75

Shouldnt this be `options = nil` like in every other Cache/Store in ActiveSupport?
This leads to `ArgumentError (wrong number of arguments (given 1, expected 0))` when passed `nil`, which can happen if the Store is abstracted and duck-typed with the original method definition `def clear(options = nil)`. E.g. it would crash in the RedisStore, if the LocalCache strategy is used, but would run fine otherwise. Even the internal LocalCache has a different signature.

title: Multiple fileupload error: Invalid request parameters: expected Array (got String) for param
body:
### Steps to reproduce

Create a form with file_field to upload multiple files.

`
<%= form_with model: submission do |f| %>
<%= f.file_field :manuscript,
                         class: 'form-control-file',
                         id: 'upload-userManuscript',
                         multiple: true,
                         accept: assignment.accepted_for_file_input %>
<% end %>
`

Try to submit this form after selecting a file. Instead of just submitting the file as parameter, there will be an empty parameter added, which causes this error.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10833180/171440254-8d527143-76ed-49c2-94b4-fbec429d328f.png)

The file_field adds an empty input field that causes this parameter to be added in the form:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10833180/171440603-35e96b71-e791-49ce-aeb6-81afbcbd182a.png)

This does not happen when the "multiple" option is set to false or when using Rails 6.

### Expected behavior

Submit request should be executed normally (status code 200)

### Actual behavior

title: Write sql query detection for Postgres extremely slow
body:
### Steps to reproduce
Feed reasonably large SQL (in my case ~ 600 lines) file with multiple query statements to ActiveRecord::Base.connection.execute while using Postgresql as database adapter and wait for results. For a long time. It is working ok in Rails 6.0.4.8 but when migrating to rails 7.0.3 one of my tests hangs for more than 5 minutes.

### To check it's the issue:
Fetched READ_QUERY from debugger just before the line that hangs:
https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/main/activerecord/lib/active_record/connection_adapters/postgresql/database_statements.rb#L30

```
read_query_regex = /\A(?:[(\s]|(?m-ix:(?:--.*\n)|\/\*(?:[^*]|\*[^\/])*\*\/))*(?-mix:(?i-mx:close)|(?i-mx:declare)|(?i-mx:fetch)|(?i-mx:move)|(?i-mx:set)|(?i-mx:show)|(?i-mx:begin)|(?i-mx:commit)|(?i-mx:explain)|(?i-mx:release)|(?i-mx:rollback)|(?i-mx:savepoint)|(?i-mx:select)|(?i-mx:with))/
sql = STDIN.read
puts read_query_regex.match?(sql)
```
### Expected behavior
It should perform the match in reasonable time, even in 1 second it would be fine

### Actual behavior
It does not finish in at least 5 minutes keeping CPU at 100%.

### System configuration
**Rails version**: 7.0.3

**Ruby version**: 3.1.2

https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/ca7c820c6962788d510c99a68e725de83cbe9cad/actionpack/lib/action_controller/metal/request_forgery_protection.rb#L48-L49

So when `commit_flash` is called there is no `enabled?` method defined on the `session` variable.

title: Where clauses with arrays including nil aren't removed by unscope
body:
### Steps to reproduce
```ruby
ActiveRecord::Schema.define do
  create_table :books, force: true do |t|
    t.string :genre
    t.string :title
  end
end

class Book < ActiveRecord::Base
  attr_accessible :genre, :title
end

Book.create!(genre: :mystery, title: 'A Study in Scarlet')
Book.create!(genre: :romance, title: 'Pride and Prejudice')
Book.create!(genre: nil, title: 'An empty book')

Book.where(genre: [nil, :romance]).unscope(where: :genre)
```

### Expected behavior
It should return all three books, regardless of genre

### Actual behavior
The SQL query still includes `WHERE ("books"."genre" = 'romance' OR "books"."genre" IS NULL)` and doesn't return A Study in Scarlet

### System configuration
**Rails version**: 4.2.11.3

**Ruby version**: 2.6.6

title: How to get blob service_url in Javascript
body:
### Steps to reproduce
Hey, I'm trying to fetch images from S3 in a JS script, which reads from a rich text editor html and extracts images src's. The problem is that when i use js `fetch`function in the redirect url, i have a cors issue and cannot get the image (that will be later converted to base64)

How can I download the blob directly from S3 in JS?

title: Flaky bug in ActionController::Parameters#permit!
body:
### Steps to reproduce
In GitHub, after upgrading to Rails 7.1 de12c18a99, a few tests have become flaky. They call endpoints with `params` that contain lists with hashes.

When the tests fail, the failure is
```
ActiveSupport::DeprecationException: DEPRECATION WARNING: Comparing equality between `ActionController::Parameters` and a `Hash` is deprecated and will be removed in Rails 7.2. Please only do comparisons between instances of `ActionController::Parameters`. If you need to compare to a hash, first convert it using `ActionController::Parameters#new`. To disable the deprecated behaviour set `Rails.application.config.action_controller.allow_deprecated_parameters_hash_equality = false`. (called from [...] at [...])
```

## Reproduction
The error is reproducible locally by running one of the tests over, over, and over again (e.g. `while bin/rails test <path-to-test>; do echo next; done`). We instrumented `ActionController::Parameters#==` (in `actionpack-7.1.0.alpha.de12c18a99/lib/action_controller/metal/strong_parameters.rb`) with a bit of backtrace stuff so it now looks like this:
```ruby
    def ==(other)
      if other.respond_to?(:permitted?)
        permitted? == other.permitted? && parameters == other.parameters
      else
        begin
          raise "We're here!"
        rescue => e
          puts e.backtrace
        end
        puts "Other class: #{other.class}"
        if Hash === other
          puts 'It is a Hash!'
        end
        if self.class.allow_deprecated_parameters_hash_equality && Hash === other
          ActiveSupport::Deprecation.warn <<-WARNING.squish
            Comparing equality between `ActionController::Parameters` and a
            `Hash` is deprecated and will be removed in Rails 7.2. Please only do
            comparisons between instances of `ActionController::Parameters`. If
            you need to compare to a hash, first convert it using
            `ActionController::Parameters#new`.
            To disable the deprecated behaviour set
            `Rails.application.config.action_controller.allow_deprecated_parameters_hash_equality = false`.
          WARNING
          @parameters == other
        else
          super
        end
      end
    end
```
...and got this nice, little stack trace:
```

/workspaces/github/vendor/gems/3.1.2/ruby/3.1.0/gems/activesupport-7.1.0.alpha.de12c18a99/lib/active_support/callbacks.rb:400:in `block in make_lambda'
/workspaces/github/vendor/gems/3.1.2/ruby/3.1.0/gems/activesupport-7.1.0.alpha.de12c18a99/lib/active_support/callbacks.rb:180:in `block (2 levels) in halting_and_conditional'
/workspaces/github/vendor/gems/3.1.2/ruby/3.1.0/gems/actionpack-7.1.0.alpha.de12c18a99/lib/abstract_controller/callbacks.rb:34:in `block (2 levels) in <module:Callbacks>'
/workspaces/github/vendor/gems/3.1.2/ruby/3.1.0/gems/activesupport-7.1.0.alpha.de12c18a99/lib/active_support/callbacks.rb:181:in `block in halting_and_conditional'
/workspaces/github/vendor/gems/3.1.2/ruby/3.1.0/gems/activesupport-7.1.0.alpha.de12c18a99/lib/active_support/callbacks.rb:595:in `block in invoke_before'
/workspaces/github/vendor/gems/3.1.2/ruby/3.1.0/gems/activesupport-7.1.0.alpha.de12c18a99/lib/active_support/callbacks.rb:595:in `each'
/workspaces/github/vendor/gems/3.1.2/ruby/3.1.0/gems/activesupport-7.1.0.alpha.de12c18a99/lib/active_support/callbacks.rb:595:in `invoke_before'
/workspaces/github/vendor/gems/3.1.2/ruby/3.1.0/gems/activesupport-7.1.0.alpha.de12c18a99/lib/active_support/callbacks.rb:116:in `block in run_callbacks'
[...more lines probably irrelevant for this issue...]
[...our test, POSTing to the endpoint...]
[...and MiniTest stack trace etc...]
Other class: ActiveSupport::HashWithIndifferentAccess
It is a Hash!
```

## Analysis
So sometimes, the implementation of `permit!` compares an `ActiveSupport::HashWithIndifferentAccess` with an `ActionController::Parameters` all by itself.

As the stack trace suggests, it happens here:
```ruby
      def convert_value_to_parameters(value)
        case value
        when Array
          return value if converted_arrays.member?(value)
          converted = value.map { |_| convert_value_to_parameters(_) }
          converted_arrays << converted.dup
          converted
        when Hash
          self.class.new(value, @logging_context)
        else
          value
        end
      end
```
(The `return value if converted_arrays.member?(value)` line.)

Most of the time, the `converted_arrays` object, which is a `Set`, will have no hash collisions with `value`, but sometimes it will, and then it needs to compare existing entries in the `Set` with `value`. And since `value` has not been converted to an `ActionController::Parameters` object, we get the error.

We have changed the `convert_value_to_parameters` method to provoke this error deterministically by making it a bit uglier and much less performant, so we compare all existing elements with `value` 
```ruby
      def convert_value_to_parameters(value)
        case value
        when Array
          match = false
          converted_arrays.each do |element|
            match ||= element == value
          end

          return value if match
          converted = value.map { |_| convert_value_to_parameters(_) }
          converted_arrays << converted.dup
          converted
        when Hash
          self.class.new(value, @logging_context)
        else
          value
        end
      end
```

## Minimal (?) test
With the changes to `convert_value_to_parameters` above, this test triggers the issue consistently:
```ruby
  test "strong parameters may be buggy" do
    ActionController::Parameters.new(
      "iterations": [
        {
          "title": "Iteration 1",
        },
      ],
      "completedIterations": [
        {
          "title": "Iteration 2",
        },
      ],
    ).permit!
  end
```
Maybe it can be made even smaller, but we're not sure.

## Possible work-around
Changing the above test a bit so that it does part of the work of `convert_value_to_parameters` can make it pass:
```ruby
  test "strong parameters may be buggy" do
    ActionController::Parameters.new(
      "iterations": [
        ActionController::Parameters.new(
          "title": "Iteration 1",
        ),
      ],
      "completedIterations": [
        ActionController::Parameters.new(
          "title": "Iteration 2",
        ),
      ],
    ).permit!
  end
```
...but this just seems wrong...? I believe the failing test should not fail, or...?

## Proposed Fix
This should fix the issue:
```ruby
      def convert_value_to_parameters(value)
        case value
        when Array
          converted = value.map { |_| convert_value_to_parameters(_) }
          return value if converted_arrays.member?(converted)
          converted_arrays << converted.dup
          converted
        when Hash
          self.class.new(value, @logging_context)
        else
          value
        end
      end
```
Now we convert the value before trying to check for membership in `converted_arrays`. This is less performant, but is maybe not too bad, since `convert_value_to_parameters` will just return the given value if it is already converted.

Maybe we can just remove the cache:
```ruby
      def convert_value_to_parameters(value)
        case value
        when Array
          value.map { |_| convert_value_to_parameters(_) }
        when Hash
          self.class.new(value, @logging_context)
        else
          value
        end
      end
```

Also, writing a test that shows a _lack_ of flakiness also needs to be done...

## Further Context
Interestingly, there was a fix in 2021 in the same method: https://github.com/rails/rails/issues/43681

But this seems to be a different issue that is related to the phasing-out of comparison between `ActionController::Parameters` and `Hash`: https://github.com/rails/rails/commit/8af86c997c7bfbb05afa7dbde8847cf9b55a7b47

(Sorry, I haven't created a reproduction script according to the template. I can do that, though the above test should be easy to get working. Let me know if I should expand on this.)

### Expected behavior
`ActionController::Parameters#permit!` shouldn't be flaky  

### Actual behavior
`ActionController::Parameters#permit!` is flaky  

### System configuration
**Rails version**: Rails 7.1.0.alpha.de12c18a99

**Ruby version**: ruby 3.1.2p20 (2022-04-12 revision 4a07381221) [x86_64-linux]

title: Associated records are validated when passing context
body:
### Steps to reproduce

```ruby
# frozen_string_literal: true

require "bundler/inline"

gemfile(true) do
  source "https://rubygems.org"

  git_source(:github) { |repo| "https://github.com/#{repo}.git" }

  # Activate the gem you are reporting the issue against.
  gem "activerecord", "~> 7.0.0"
  gem "sqlite3"
end

require "active_record"
require "minitest/autorun"
require "logger"

# This connection will do for database-independent bug reports.
ActiveRecord::Base.establish_connection(adapter: "sqlite3", database: ":memory:")
ActiveRecord::Base.logger = Logger.new(STDOUT)

ActiveRecord::Schema.define do
  create_table :posts, force: true do |t|
  end

  create_table :comments, force: true do |t|
    t.integer :post_id
    t.string :body
  end
end

class Post < ActiveRecord::Base
  has_many :comments

  after_create :create_invalid_comment!

  def create_invalid_comment!
    c = comments.new
    c.save!(validate: false)
  end
end

class Comment < ActiveRecord::Base
  belongs_to :post

  validates :body, presence: true
end

class BugTest < Minitest::Test
  def test_save
    post = Post.create
    assert post.save
  end

  def test_save_with_context
    post = Post.create
    assert post.save(context: :whatever)
  end

  def test_save_with_context_reloaded
    post = Post.create.reload
    assert post.save(context: :whatever)
  end
end
```

### Expected behavior

Associated records are not validated.

### Actual behavior

Associated records are validated.

### System configuration
**Rails version**: Rails 7.0.3

**Ruby version**: ruby 3.1.2p20 (2022-04-12 revision 4491bb740a) [x86_64-linux]

title: Improve documentation on discarding active storage files during and after system tests
body:
### Steps to reproduce

I am running system tests using minitest and active-storage file fixtures. `#destroy` callbacks are not run when database transactions are rolled back. Therefore we need to cleanup after ourselves. [The documentation](https://guides.rubyonrails.org/active_storage_overview.html#discarding-files-created-during-tests) suggests the following method should be added to `ApplicationSystemTestCase`:

```ruby
class ApplicationSystemTestCase < ActionDispatch::SystemTestCase
  # ...
  def after_teardown
    super
    FileUtils.rm_rf(ActiveStorage::Blob.service.root)
  end
  # ...
end
```

However, if this technique is used in combination with [ActiveStorage File Fixtures](https://edgeguides.rubyonrails.org/active_storage_overview.html#adding-attachments-to-fixtures), the files added by the fixture files (`active_storage/blobs.yml` and `active_storage/attachments.yml`) get cleaned up as well. The results are cryptic and random `ActiveStorage::FileNotFoundError` errors when running system tests. Debugging is also very hard, since these errors are not reproducible when running single tests in order to isolate the problem.

It is also important to note that `after_teardown` gets run after test, instead of after the whole suite finishes. 

### Expected behavior

The documentation should either warn about this problem, or suggest a different solution.

### Actual behavior

The code copy-and-pasted from the documentation results in random system test failures, which are hard to get a hold of.

### Proposed Changes

#### My preferred solution
File name collisions in the disk service are very unlikely to happen when performing a single-test run of the whole test suite. Therefore, I am suggesting to just cleanup the active storage directory after the whole test suite has finished by using minitest's `after_run` hook:

```ruby
# test/test_helper.rb

# ...

Minitest.after_run do
  FileUtils.rm_rf(ActiveStorage::Blob.service.root)
end
```

#### Alternate solution

We could also suggest using a different storage location for files added by fixture files. I would need to look into how we could implement this solution.

### System configuration
**Rails version**:
7.0.3

**Ruby version**:
3.0.2p107

title: Deterministically encrypted attributes are uniquely validated N + 1 times when `extend_queries` is enabled
body:
### Steps to reproduce

```ruby
# frozen_string_literal: true

require "bundler/inline"

gemfile(true) do
  source "https://rubygems.org"

  git_source(:github) { |repo| "https://github.com/#{repo}.git" }

  # Activate the gem you are reporting the issue against.
  gem "activerecord"
  gem "sqlite3"
end

require "active_record"
require "minitest/autorun"
require "logger"

# This connection will do for database-independent bug reports.
ActiveRecord::Base.establish_connection(adapter: "sqlite3", database: ":memory:")
ActiveRecord::Base.logger = Logger.new(STDOUT)

ActiveRecord::Encryption.configure(
  primary_key: SecureRandom.alphanumeric(32),
  deterministic_key: SecureRandom.alphanumeric(32),
  key_derivation_salt: SecureRandom.alphanumeric(32),
)

ActiveRecord::Encryption::ExtendedDeterministicUniquenessValidator.install_support

ActiveRecord::Schema.define do
  create_table :companies, force: true do |t|
    t.string :a, null: false, index: { unique: true }
    t.string :b, null: false, index: { unique: true }
  end
end

class Company < ActiveRecord::Base
  validates :a, uniqueness: true
  validates :b, uniqueness: true

  encrypts :a, deterministic: true
  encrypts :b, deterministic: true
end

class BugTest < ActiveSupport::TestCase
  include ActiveRecord::TestFixtures

  self.use_transactional_tests = true

  def test_uniqueness_validations_for_deterministically_encrypted_attributes
    Company.create!(a: '1', b: '2')
    Company.create!(a: '1', b: '2')

    # look at the # of queries performed in the SQL output
  end
end
```

### Expected behavior

`Company#a` and `Company#b` are only validated for uniqueness once (unless `:previous` is configured, in which case it would do `1 + n`, where `n` is the number of previous encryption schemes for that _single_ attribute).

### Actual behavior

`Company#a` and `Company#b` are validated 3 times each, even with no previous encryption schemes for either attribute.

If `ActiveRecord::Encryption.config.extend_queries` has been enabled, uniqueness validation is extended here:

https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/01f58d62c2f31f42d0184e0add2b6aa710513695/activerecord/lib/active_record/railtie.rb#L350-L354

I would expect this to run additional validations against previous encryption schemes, if any existed. However, it appears to be iterating over the # of deterministically encrypted attributes, performing the validation many additional times.

### System configuration
**Rails version**: 7.0.3

**Ruby version**: 3.1.2

title: ActiveSupport::Reloader.to_prepare do runs before autoload_paths
body:
### Steps to reproduce
I have this in my application.rb
```
class Application < Rails::Application
    config.load_defaults 7.0
    config.autoload_paths += Dir["#{config.root}/lib/**/"]
    ...
```

I have this in a file config/initializers/good_job.rb:

```
ActiveSupport::Reloader.to_prepare do
  Cameras::Hikvision
end
```

I have this in my ./lib/cameras/hikvision.rb:
```
class Cameras::Hikvision
end
```

When I start my app, I see:

```
uninitialized constant Cameras::Hikvision
```

### Expected behaviour

I am expecting Rails to load the autoload_paths (which include "#{config.root}/lib/**/") before loading my initializers, which depend on the former.


### Actual behaviour

It seems to first load the initializers before my libraries.

### System configuration
**Rails version**: 7.0.3
**Ruby version**: 3.1.2


Any ideas? - Maybe I need to use something other than ActiveSupport::Reloader.to_prepare?

title: `minitest` is a runtime dependency of `activesupport`
body:
### Steps to reproduce

I've noticed `minitest` in a project's `Gemfile.lock`, while the project exclusively uses RSpec.
It turns out that [`minitest` is a runtime dependency of `activesupport`](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/4d5a570cfe1890f71a1d198a5fe40d528f2b60d4/activesupport/activesupport.gemspec#L40).
Other Rails gems don't seem to specify `minitest` at all, e.g. [`activerecord`](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/4d5a570cfe1890f71a1d198a5fe40d528f2b60d4/activerecord/activerecord.gemspec#L38), [`activejob`](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/4d5a570cfe1890f71a1d198a5fe40d528f2b60d4/activejob/activejob.gemspec#L35).

It's not a big deal, but shaving off 150KB of code from each deployment is a nice bonus.

I can track this down to [this commit](https://github.com/rails/rails/commit/6f74d36c4263a6cbbc6dc32a03edeed04faefbd9) that moved `minitest` from the `Gemfile` (development only) to `gemspec`.
`add_development_dependency` was introduced a couple of years before this commit, [in `rubygems` 1.2](https://github.com/rubygems/rubygems/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#120--2008-06-21) but probably Rails couldn't rely on a wider adoption. Now, nearly a decade later, this should be possible.

I'll be happy to work on a PR for that.

### Expected behavior

1. `minitest` is a development dependency
2. `minitest` is explicitly specified as a development dependency for each Rails gem

### Actual behavior

`minitest` is bundled along with the application code for production deployment

### System configuration

**Rails version**: 6.0.5 (4.0.0 up to latest 7.0)

**Ruby version**: any

`end`

title: DateTime#parse setting time zone not accounting for DST
body:
### Steps to reproduce

I believe `DateTime#parse` is not correctly accounting for daylight savings time in the date parse. 

When I run:
```ruby
3.1.2 :033 > DateTime.parse("2022-05-24T19:00 Pacific Time (US & Canada)")
 => Tue, 24 May 2022 19:00:00 -0800
```
But I would expect to get a -7 offset because in May, Pacific time is -7, not -8. We know this because today happens to be May 24th, so I can run:

```ruby 
3.1.2 :032 > DateTime.current.in_time_zone("Pacific Time (US & Canada)")
 => Tue, 24 May 2022 19:37:09.580579000 PDT -07:00
```

### Expected behavior
```ruby 
DateTime.parse("2022-05-24T09:00 Pacific Time (US & Canada)")
=> Tue, 24 May 2022 09:00:00 -0700
```

### Additional Note
This leads us to this unfortunate state:

```ruby
3.1.2 :035 > DateTime.parse("2022-05-24T19:00 Pacific Time (US & Canada)").in_time_zone("Pacific Time (US & Canada)")
 => Tue, 24 May 2022 20:00:00.000000000 PDT -07:00
```
Converting into the time zone we thought we parsed in "changes" the time by an hour

### System configuration
**Rails version**: 7.0.3

**Ruby version**:  3.1

title: Hash#to_xml generates invalid XML when keys are numbers
body:
### Steps to reproduce
Call to_xml on a hash that has integers/stringified integers keys.

```ruby
> hash = { 1 => 'foo' }
=> {1=>"foo"}
> hash.to_xml
=> "<?xml version=\"1.0\" encoding=\"UTF-8\"?>\n<hash>\n  <1>foo</1>\n</hash>\n"

> hash = { '1' => 'foo' }
=> {"1"=>"foo"}
> hash.to_xml
=> "<?xml version=\"1.0\" encoding=\"UTF-8\"?>\n<hash>\n  <1>foo</1>\n</hash>\n"
```

### Expected behavior
Valid XMLs expected

### Actual behavior
Both generated XMLs are invalid since "1" is not a valid XML element. Element names must start with a letter or underscore. 

### System configuration
**Rails version**: 6.1.5.1

**Ruby version**: 3.1.2p20 (2022-04-12 revision 4491bb740a) [x86_64-darwin21]

title: Error after upgrading: undefined method `content_tag' for ActionView::Base:Class.
body:
I found this in a large project by upgrading to Rails 7 and I noticed a ton of Active Scaffold errors but after turning `BACKTRACE=1` on I found the culprit. In a Rails 6.0 project I can run `ActionView::Base.field_error_proc.call` and I get `"
"`, but in Rails 7 I get: ``` [1] pry(main)> ActionView::Base.field_error_proc.call NoMethodError: undefined method `content_tag' for ActionView::Base:Class Did you mean? const_get from /Users/gns/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.7.2@rxg/gems/actionview-7.0.3/lib/action_view/base.rb:145:in `block in ' ``` ### Steps to reproduce Open console in a Rail 7.0.3 project and run `ActionView::Base.field_error_proc.call`. ### Expected behavior I would assume that `ActionView::Base.field_error_proc.call` should work just like it did in Rails 6. ### Actual behavior ``` [1] pry(main)> ActionView::Base.field_error_proc.call NoMethodError: undefined method `content_tag' for ActionView::Base:Class Did you mean? const_get from /Users/gns/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.7.2@rxg/gems/actionview-7.0.3/lib/action_view/base.rb:145:in `block in ' ``` ### System configuration **Rails version**: 7.0.3 **Ruby version**: ruby 2.7.2p137 (2020-10-01 revision 5445e04352) [x86_64-darwin20]

title: test_db:prepare_creates_test_database_if_it_does_not_exist fails
body:
Managed to reproduce https://buildkite.com/rails/rails/builds/86697#914ae9c5-1469-4269-b24b-202e6b5e07f0 via https://github.com/rails/rails/pull/45157

title: Delegator parent is never touched
body:
### Steps to reproduce
<!-- (Guidelines for creating a bug report are [available
here](https://edgeguides.rubyonrails.org/contributing_to_ruby_on_rails.html#creating-a-bug-report)) -->

<!-- Paste your executable test case created from one of the scripts found [here](https://edgeguides.rubyonrails.org/contributing_to_ruby_on_rails.html#create-an-executable-test-case) below: -->
```ruby
# frozen_string_literal: true

require "bundler/inline"

gemfile(true) do
  source "https://rubygems.org"

  git_source(:github) { |repo| "https://github.com/#{repo}.git" }

  # Activate the gem you are reporting the issue against.
  gem "activerecord", "~> 7.0.0"
  gem "sqlite3"
end

require "active_record"
require "minitest/autorun"
require "logger"

# This connection will do for database-independent bug reports.
ActiveRecord::Base.establish_connection(adapter: "sqlite3", database: ":memory:")
ActiveRecord::Base.logger = Logger.new(STDOUT)

ActiveRecord::Schema.define do
  create_table :users, force: true do |t|
    t.datetime :created_at, null: false
    t.datetime :updated_at, null: false
  end

  create_table :profiles, force: true do |t|
    t.bigint :user_id
    t.string :profilable_type
    t.bigint :profilable_id

    #t.datetime :created_at, null: false
    #t.datetime :updated_at, null: false
  end

  create_table :doctors, force: true do |t|
    t.string :name

    #t.datetime :created_at, null: false
    #t.datetime :updated_at, null: false
  end

  create_table :patients, force: true do |t|
    t.string :name

    #t.datetime :created_at, null: false
    #t.datetime :updated_at, null: false
  end

  create_table :skills, force: true do |t|
    t.bigint :doctor_id
    t.string :name
  end
end

class User < ActiveRecord::Base
  has_one :profile
end

class Profile < ActiveRecord::Base
  delegated_type :profilable, types: %w[ doctor patient ]

  belongs_to :user, touch: true
end

class Patient < ActiveRecord::Base
  has_one :profile, as: :profilable, touch: true
end

class Doctor < ActiveRecord::Base
  has_one  :profile, as: :profilable, touch: true
  has_many :skills
end

class Skill < ActiveRecord::Base
  belongs_to :doctor, touch: true
end

class BugTest < Minitest::Test
  def test_touching_user_after_add_doctors_skill
    new_doctor  = Doctor.new name: "sebastian"
    new_profile = Profile.new profilable: new_doctor

    user = User.create!(profile: new_profile)

    # previously_doctor_updated_at  = user.profile.profilable.updated_at
    # previously_profile_updated_at = user.profile.updated_at
    previously_user_updated_at    = user.updated_at

    user.profile.profilable.skills.create!(name: "diabetes_management")

    # assert(previously_doctor_updated_at  != user.profile.profilable.reload.updated_at) # ok
    # assert(previously_profile_updated_at != user.profile.reload.updated_at) # ok
    assert(previously_user_updated_at    != user.reload.updated_at) # failed
  end
end
```

### Expected behavior
1 - When a doctors' skill is added, the user should be touched since the touch flow is skill -> doctor -> profile -> user. 
2 - If there's no timestamps on the doctor, the profile should be touched as well.

### Actual behavior
1 - When a doctor's skill is added, doctor and profile are touched, but not the user.
2 - If there's no timestamps on the doctor, the profile is not touched along with the user.

### System configuration
**Rails version**:
Rails 7.0.3

**Ruby version**:
Ruby ruby 3.1.1

title: Proposal: Improve logging format from QueryLogs
body:
**Note: This proposal is currently being implemented here: https://github.com/rails/rails/pull/45081**

Im looking for feedback on a proposal to improve the formatting of auto-injected SQL comments in Rails 7 (via [QueryLogs](https://blog.saeloun.com/2021/09/15/rails-maginalia-query-logs.html)). It seems like the current format for SQL comments isnt correct, because:

1. It isnt really machine-readable
2. It doesnt adhere to existing standards, like [sqlcommenter](https://open-telemetry.github.io/opentelemetry-sqlcommenter/ruby/)

For example, auto-commented SQL queries using Marginalia/Rails look like this:
`"select id from posts; /*application:Joe's app,controller:my_controller*/"`

and I'm proposing a format to use the sqlcommenter syntax like so:
`"select id from posts; /*application='Joe\\'s app',controller='my_controller'*/"`

The latter can be parsed much more easily, and will also automatically report metrics by [databases that support the sqlcommenter formatting](https://cloud.google.com/sql/docs/postgres/using-query-insights#adding-tags-to-sql-queries).

This also feels like a good time to propose a change because it's relatively new functionality, before too many folks develop a dependency on the format.

title: Suggestion: "ActiveDocument" Rails + NoSql
body:
Throwing an idea out there: "ActiveDocument", equivalent to ActiveRecord but to provide first class support for NoSQL databases.

There are a number of DBs out there: Couchbase, MongoDB, Elasticsearch, Amazon DynamoDB, etc. In many of these cases the vendor is making its own platform-specific gem. Perhaps its time for Rails team to take ownership here? Thoughts?

title: has_one generates incorrect queries
body:
### Steps to reproduce

### Expected behavior

```ruby
# frozen_string_literal: true

require "bundler/inline"

gemfile(true) do
  source "https://rubygems.org"

  git_source(:github) { |repo| "https://github.com/#{repo}.git" }

  gem "rails", github: "rails/rails", branch: "main"
  gem "sqlite3"
end

require "active_record"
require "minitest/autorun"
require "logger"

# This connection will do for database-independent bug reports.
ActiveRecord::Base.establish_connection(adapter: "sqlite3", database: ":memory:")
ActiveRecord::Base.logger = Logger.new(STDOUT)

ActiveRecord::Schema.define do
  create_table :things, force: true do |t|
    t.integer :parent_id
  end
end

class Thing < ActiveRecord::Base
  belongs_to :parent, foreign_key: :parent_id, class_name: :Thing
  has_one :child, foreign_key: :parent_id, class_name: :Thing
end

class BugTest < Minitest::Test
  def test_association_stuff
    parent_without_child = Thing.create!(parent_id: nil)
    parent_with_child = Thing.create!(parent_id: nil)
    child = Thing.create!(parent: parent_with_child)

    # Here are 4 queries that I believe should be equivalent, but they are not.

    # These two queries produce correct results
    correct_queries = [
      Thing.where.not(child: Thing.all.to_a).to_a,
      Thing.where.not(child: Thing.where.not(parent_id: nil)).to_a,
    ]

    correct_queries.each do |things_without_children|
      assert_includes(things_without_children, parent_without_child)
      refute_includes(things_without_children, parent_with_child)
      assert_includes(things_without_children, child)
    end

    # These two produce incorrect results
    incorrect_queries = [
      Thing.where.not(child: Thing.all).to_a,
      Thing.where(child: nil).to_a,
    ]

    incorrect_queries.each do |things_without_children|
      assert_includes(things_without_children, parent_without_child)
      refute_includes(things_without_children, parent_with_child)
      assert_includes(things_without_children, child)
    end
  end
end
```

### System configuration
**Rails version**:

7.0.3

**Ruby version**:

3.0.3

title: `rename_table` does not work for tables with very long table names when using PostgreSQL
body:
Index names in PostgreSQL are limited to 64 characters. When creating a table with a very long name, the name of the index for the primary key is automatically truncated (by PotsgreSQL) so that it fits in 64 characters.

When trying to rename such a table, ActiveRecord apparently infers a wrong index name.

### Steps to reproduce
:warning: First you have to start a postgres server. Do this with `docker run --rm -e POSTGRES_PASSWORD=mysecretpassword -p "5432:5432" postgres:14.3`

```ruby
# frozen_string_literal: true

require "bundler/inline"

gemfile(true) do
  source "https://rubygems.org"

  git_source(:github) { |repo| "https://github.com/#{repo}.git" }

  # Activate the gem you are reporting the issue against.
  gem "activerecord", "~> 7.0.0"
  gem "pg"
end

require "active_record"
require "minitest/autorun"
require "logger"

# This connection will do for database-independent bug reports.
ActiveRecord::Base.establish_connection(adapter: "postgresql", host: "localhost", username: 'postgres', password: 'mysecretpassword')
ActiveRecord::Base.logger = Logger.new(STDOUT)

class BlorgMigration < ActiveRecord::Migration[7.0]
  def change
    create_table(:this_works)
    create_table(:this_is_a_really_long_table_name_for_all_banana_plants_on_this_planet)
    rename_table(:this_works, :this_still_works)
    rename_table(:this_is_a_really_long_table_name_for_all_banana_plants_on_this_planet, :this_is_broken)
  end
end

class BugTest < Minitest::Test
  def test_migration_up
    BlorgMigration.migrate(:up)
  end
end

```

### Expected behavior
This migration should run without throwing an error

### Actual behavior
This migration throws the following error:

```
ActiveRecord::StatementInvalid: PG::UndefinedTable: ERROR:  relation "this_is_a_really_long_table_name_for_all_banana_plants_on_this_" does not exist
```

### Log

In the logfile we can see that renaming the table does work, but renaming the index (created for the primary key) does not:

```
==  BlorgMigration: migrating =================================================
-- create_table(:this_works)
D, [2022-05-19T15:40:45.310776 #158967] DEBUG -- :    (11.4ms)  CREATE TABLE "this_works" ("id" bigserial primary key)
   -> 0.0120s
-- create_table(:this_is_a_really_long_table_name_for_all_banana_plants_on_this_planet)
D, [2022-05-19T15:40:45.318886 #158967] DEBUG -- :    (7.5ms)  CREATE TABLE "this_is_a_really_long_table_name_for_all_banana_plants_on_this_planet" ("id" bigserial primary key)
   -> 0.0079s
-- rename_table(:this_works, :this_still_works)
D, [2022-05-19T15:40:45.322836 #158967] DEBUG -- :    (2.6ms)  ALTER TABLE "this_works" RENAME TO "this_still_works"
D, [2022-05-19T15:40:45.328821 #158967] DEBUG -- :    (2.8ms)  ALTER INDEX "this_works_pkey" RENAME TO "this_still_works_pkey"
D, [2022-05-19T15:40:45.331602 #158967] DEBUG -- :    (2.6ms)  ALTER TABLE "public"."this_works_id_seq" RENAME TO "this_still_works_id_seq"
   -> 0.0144s
-- rename_table(:this_is_a_really_long_table_name_for_all_banana_plants_on_this_planet, :this_is_broken)
D, [2022-05-19T15:40:45.336856 #158967] DEBUG -- :    (2.9ms)  ALTER TABLE "this_is_a_really_long_table_name_for_all_banana_plants_on_this_planet" RENAME TO "this_is_broken"
D, [2022-05-19T15:40:45.338502 #158967] DEBUG -- :    (0.4ms)  ALTER INDEX "this_is_a_really_long_table_name_for_all_banana_plants_on_this_planet_pkey" RENAME TO "this_is_broken_pkey"
E
```

### System configuration
**Ruby version**: ruby 2.7.4p191 (2021-07-07 revision a21a3b7d23) [x86_64-linux]

title: Decryption is not working for IN queries
body:
Active record encryption is not decrypting array parameters. 
- It doesn't work. `Physician.where(occupation: ["one", "two"])`
- It works with arrays with a single value. `Physician.where(occupation: ["one"])`
- It works with has_many. `Physician.where(languages: { name: ["PT", "EN"] })`

### Steps to reproduce
<!-- (Guidelines for creating a bug report are [available
here](https://edgeguides.rubyonrails.org/contributing_to_ruby_on_rails.html#creating-a-bug-report)) -->

<!-- Paste your executable test case created from one of the scripts found [here](https://edgeguides.rubyonrails.org/contributing_to_ruby_on_rails.html#create-an-executable-test-case) below: -->
```ruby
class Physician < ApplicationRecord
  encrypts :medical_school, :degree, :occupation, deterministic: true
end
```

```ruby
Physician.where(occupation: ["one", "two"])
```

### Expected behavior
<!-- Tell us what should happen -->
```SQL
SELECT * FROM "physicians" WHERE "physicians"."occupation" IN ($1, $2) ["occupation", "one"], ["occupation", "two"]
```

### Actual behavior
<!-- Tell us what happens instead -->
```SQL
SELECT * FROM "physicians" WHERE "physicians"."occupation" IN ($1, $2) ["occupation", "encrypted"], ["occupation", "encrypted"]
```

### System configuration
**Rails version**: 7.0.3

**Ruby version**: 3.1.1

title: Very long test output even for simple failing tests
body:
### Steps to reproduce

The test output in some cases is extremely long, making it difficult to see what the error is. (As far as I can tell, this is a regression; I dont recall the issue being present in earlier versions of Rails.) The issue is currently affecting readers of the *Ruby on Rails Tutorial* 7th edition, including me (its author).

The issue is easy to reproduce with the latest version of Rails (7.0.3 as of this writing) and a simple generated Pages controller (with one action, `home`):

```
$ gem install rails -v 7.0.3
$ rails _7.0.3_ new test_output_app
$ cd test_output_app/
$ rails generate controller Pages home
$ rails test
Running 1 tests in a single process (parallelization threshold is 50)
Run options: --seed 60583

# Running:

.

Finished in 0.616127s, 1.6230 runs/s, 1.6230 assertions/s.
1 runs, 1 assertions, 0 failures, 0 errors, 0 skips
```

The tests initially pass, but we can reproduce the issue by commenting out the route for the home page in `config/routes.rb`:

```
Rails.application.routes.draw do
  # get 'pages/home'        <-- this is the line that should be commented out
  # Define your application routes per the DSL in https://guides.rubyonrails.org/routing.html

  # Defines the root path route ("/")
  # root "articles#index"
end
```

This causes the generated test in `test/controllers/pages_controller_test.rb` to fail because `pages_home_url` is no longer defined:

```
require "test_helper"

class PagesControllerTest < ActionDispatch::IntegrationTest
  test "should get home" do
    get pages_home_url
    assert_response :success
  end
end
```

At this point, running `rails test` outputs a tremendous volume of text:

```
$ rails test
Running 1 tests in a single process (parallelization threshold is 50)
Run options: --seed 23908

# Running:

E

Error:
PagesControllerTest#test_should_get_home:
NameError: undefined local variable or method `pages_home_url' for 
.
.
.
```

The vertical dots here indicate a large amount of omitted text.

### Expected behavior

The output of `rails test` for this single failing test should be fairly short, making it easy to identify the precise issue and file line numbersomething like this:

```
$ rails test
Running 1 tests in a single process (parallelization threshold is 50)
Run options: --seed 23908

# Running:

E

Error:
PagesControllerTest#test_should_get_home:
NameError: undefined local variable or method `pages_home_url' for #<PagesControllerTest:0x0000000104f598a8>
rails test test/controllers/pages_controller_test.rb:4



Finished in 0.122953s, 8.1332 runs/s, 0.0000 assertions/s.
1 runs, 0 assertions, 0 failures, 1 errors, 0 skips
```

This would work out to around 50 words and 440 characters of total output.

### Actual behavior

The actual output is enormousover 9,000 words and nearly 320,000 characters of total output:

```
$ rails test | wc
      18    9049  319394
```

The output is so voluminous that on many systems (including mine) it overflows the terminals ability to scroll back. Its possible to route around the problem in a narrow sense by piping to `grep`, but this is an awkward hack, doesnt work well when there are multiple failing tests, and doesnt work at all with an automated test runner like Guard.

### System configuration

**Rails version**: 7.0.3

**Ruby version**: 3.1.2

I have reproduced the issue both on my MacBook (running macOS Monterey 12.3.1) and on AWS Cloud9 (running Ubuntu Linux).

N.B. [This Stack Overflow issue](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/66593801/rails-test-command-prints-out-a-very-long-output) seems to allude to the same behavior, though unfortunately no solution has been forthcoming.

title: ComparisonValidator example code does not work
body:
### Steps to reproduce

```ruby
# frozen_string_literal: true

require "bundler/inline"

gemfile(true) do
  source "https://rubygems.org"

  git_source(:github) { |repo| "https://github.com/#{repo}.git" }

end

require "active_record"

require "logger"

# This connection will do for database-independent bug reports.
ActiveRecord::Base.establish_connection(adapter: "sqlite3", database: ":memory:")
ActiveRecord::Base.logger = Logger.new(STDOUT)

ActiveRecord::Schema.define do
  create_table :people, force: true do |t|
    t.date :birth_date
  end
end

class Person < ActiveRecord::Base
  validates_comparison_of :birth_date, less_than_or_equal_to: -> { Date.today }
end

class BugTest < Minitest::Test
  def test_comparison_validator
    person = Person.create!(birth_date: Date.yesterday)

    assert_equal 1, Person.count
  end
end
```

### Expected behavior

```
1 runs, 1 assertions, 0 failures, 0 errors, 0 skips
```

### Actual behavior

```
Error:
BugTest#test_comparison_validator:
ActiveRecord::RecordInvalid: Validation failed: Birth date wrong number of arguments (given 1, expected 0)

1 runs, 0 assertions, 0 failures, 1 errors, 0 skips
```

I tried example code.
https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/v7.0.3/activemodel/lib/active_model/validations/comparison.rb#L74=
```ruby
      # For example:
      #
      #   class Person < ActiveRecord::Base
      #     validates_comparison_of :birth_date, less_than_or_equal_to: -> { Date.today }
      #     validates_comparison_of :preferred_name, other_than: :given_name, allow_nil: true
      #   end
```

PR: https://github.com/rails/rails/pull/40095
There seems to be no test for `-> { }`.

This works.
```ruby
validates_comparison_of :birth_date, less_than_or_equal_to: Proc.new { Date.today }
```

### System configuration
**Rails version**: 7.0.3

**Ruby version**: 3.1.2

title: ActiveSupport::Duration#iso8601 number with e notation
body:
### Steps to reproduce
<!-- (Guidelines for creating a bug report are [available
here](https://edgeguides.rubyonrails.org/contributing_to_ruby_on_rails.html#creating-a-bug-report)) -->

<!-- Paste your executable test case created from one of the scripts found [here](https://edgeguides.rubyonrails.org/contributing_to_ruby_on_rails.html#create-an-executable-test-case) below: -->
```ruby
big_number = 1_000_000_000

iso_duration_string = big_number.seconds.iso8601 # "PT1e+09S"

parsed_duration = ActiveSupport::Duration.parse(iso_duration_string) 
```

### Expected behavior
<!-- Tell us what should happen -->
The `iso_duration_string` should be equal to `"PT1000000000S"`
or 
`ActiveSupport::Duration#parse` should be able to parse it back 

### Actual behavior
<!-- Tell us what happens instead -->
an error is raised :  
```ruby
ActiveSupport::Duration::ISO8601Parser::ParsingError: Invalid ISO 8601 duration: "PT1e+09S" 
# at 
active_support/duration/iso8601_parser.rb:97:in `raise_parsing_error'
```

### System configuration
**Rails version**: Rails 6.0.3.2

**Ruby version**: ruby 2.6.5p114


### Informations
strangely, when specifying a precision, the bug does not appear
```ruby
big_number.seconds.iso8601(precision: 0) # "PT1000000000S"
```
Or when it comes to hours
```ruby
big_number.hours.iso8601 # "PT1000000000H"
```

title: Configuration for multiple databases unable to establish connection.
body:
Context: Building a distributed database system with multiple mixed single vs main/replica databases.

[not directly related to the issue, but relevant to this observer] I would like to mention that [the relative rails guide](https://guides.rubyonrails.org/active_record_multiple_databases.html) is lacking on a couple of fundamental points.
1) postgresql has mechanisms for ensuring replication for users with that role attributed.  I have to assume that these users needed to be created with that attibuted role given the guide is totally mute on the subject of user creation.  
2) postresql has its own instruction set for setting up replicating data. This leads to a second assumption : Rails handles this aspect as it knows about both data stores in database.yml.  If this assumption is wrong then the guide is utterly lacking.

With two assumptions we are entering a geometric sphere of possibilities.  Additionally these two are, on the face of it contradictory: first case => intervene on postgresql, second case => not.
[end of mention]

### Steps to reproduce
```
production:
  primary:
    adapter: postgresql
    encoding: unicode
    host: central.domain.ws
    username: deploy_root
    password: pwd_root
    database: users
    pool: 50
  primary_replica:
    adapter: postgresql
    encoding: unicode
    host: replica.domain.ws
    username: deploy_readonly
    password: pwd_readonly
    database: users
    pool: 50
    replica: true
  forum:
    adapter: postgresql
    encoding: unicode
    database: fora
    username: deploy_root
    password: pwd_root
    host: central.domain.ws
    migrations_paths: db/forum_migrate
  forum_replica:
    adapter: postgresql
    encoding: unicode
    database: fora
    username: deploy_readonly
    password: pwd_readonly
    host: replica.domain.ws
    replica: true
  franchise:
    adapter: postgresql
    encoding: unicode
    database: franchise
    username: deploy_root
    password: pwd_root
    host: central.domain.ws
    migrations_paths: db/franchise_migrate
```
### Expected behavior
Migration proceeds as by design

### Actual behavior
Two error behaviours are observed and they are not consistent with each other.

The second came about as a means of testing the migration command.  Note: `bin/rails db:migrate` would not run.
Logging into the server and launching from the releases directory
```
bundle exec rake db:migrate
rake aborted!
ActiveRecord::DatabaseConnectionError: There is an issue connecting to your database with your username/password, username: deploy_root.

Please check your database configuration to ensure the username/password are valid.
/home/deploy_root/franchise/shared/bundle/ruby/3.1.0/gems/activerecord-7.0.3/lib/active_record/connection_adapters/postgresql_adapter.rb:83:in `rescue in new_client'
```

title: Should "defaults" initializer be loaded at the same time that defaults version is?
body: Important note: I reference Rails 5 as our current working app version, but I created a test app and gem on Rails main branch (7.1.0-alpha) and Ruby 3.0.1. I verified the same issue still exists using that configuration. --- We are working on upgrading a Rails 5 app and we were confused why a change in `config/initializers/new_framework_defaults_5_2.rb` didn't seem to be working. It was: ```ruby Rails.application.config.action_controller.default_protect_from_forgery = true ``` It turns out we had older versions of a couple of gems that were causing `ActionController` to be loaded earlier than it should have been. #### Expected execution order The expected execution order of the code is: - `application.rb` - initializers in `config/initializers` - https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/main/actionpack/lib/action_controller/railtie.rb#L101-L107 When the code executes in this order, forgery is setup as expected. However, this is not the case if a gem accesses `ActionController::Base` prematurely by not using a railtie. #### Actual execution order When a gem accesses `ActionController::Base` without using a railtie containing something like `ActiveSupport.on_load(:action_controller_base)`, the execution order is: - `application.rb` - https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/main/actionpack/lib/action_controller/railtie.rb#L101-L107 - initializers in `config/initializers` Since the initializers haven't run when the second item (`railtie.rb#L101-L107`) is executed, forgery protection isn't setup as expected. You can see a screenshot of my debuggers being hit in the unexpected order below: --- There are numerous other examples of this bug, as seen [here](https://github.com/rails/rails/issues/39855#issuecomment-659670294). We believe the reason that this is happening is because gems are loaded between `application.rb` and the `config/initializers` files. Because of this, gems have a chance to access things too early and cause premature loading of Rails components. We have come up with two conceptual ways to fix this. #### 1. Move default overrides out of initializers If default overrides were loaded at the same place as defaults, it could look something like this: ```ruby # application.rb ... load_defaults 5.0 load_default_overrides ... ``` ```ruby # elsewhere in Rails bootstrap or config object def load_default_overrides Dir.glob('config/defaults/*.rb').each do |f| require f end end ``` The overrides could then live in files like `config/defaults/5_2.rb`. This solution would remove the chance for any gem to load between `load_defaults` being called and overrides being set. #### 2. Raise on early loading If a gem loads any of the rails components before Rails is ready for them to be loaded, Rails could raise an error. The bug presented in this issue could affect any initializer in an application. Raising an error if Rails isn't done loading when one of the components is accessed would protect every initializer in the application. ### Main branch reproduction I created a test gem with this code: ```ruby # frozen_string_literal: true require_relative "test_rails_initializers/version" module TestRailsInitializers ActionController::Base.prepend Module.new end ``` This code replicates the bug on the current main branch: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/543973/168493558-1ef88c2d-7abe-4a8f-aa6a-a21c059295c5.png) ### System configuration **Rails version**: 5.x all the way through main branch (currently 7.1.0-alpha) **Ruby version**: 2.6 - 3.0.1 tested

title: Rails 7.0.3 changes `t.references` in 6.0 migrations from `t.integer` to `t.bigint` on PostgreSQL.
body:
After upgrading Rails from 7.0.2.4 to 7.0.3, `rake db:drop db:create db:migrate` is producing changes in our `db/schema.rb`, from our `6.0` migrations which I wouldn't expect after an upgrade. I can't tell whether this is a new bug being introduced or a previous bug being fixed.

### Steps to reproduce

 - Here is a newly generated example 7.0.2.4 application with some 6.0 migrations and 7.0 migrations: https://github.com/andrewculver/rails-migration-issue
 - Here is a PR on that same repository where we upgrade from 7.0.2.4 to 7.0.3 and ran `rake db:drop db:create db:migrate` to produce the delta in `db/schema.rb`: https://github.com/andrewculver/rails-migration-issue/pull/1/files

Here are the steps I performed to generate that repository and PR:

```bash
mkdir old-rails
cd old-rails
echo "source 'https://rubygems.org'" > "Gemfile"
echo "gem 'rails', '7.0.2.4'" >> "Gemfile"
bundle install
bundle exec rails -v
# Confirm it says "7.0.2.4"
rails new migration-issue-app --database=postgresql
cd migration-issue-app

rm ./Gemfile.lock
vim ./Gemfile
# Lock "rails" at "7.0.2.4".
bundle install

rails g model Project name:string
rails g model Idea project:references name:string
vim db/migrate/*_create_projects.rb
# Change migration version to "6.0".
vim db/migrate/*_create_ideas.rb
# Change migration version to "6.0".

rails g model Site name:string
rails g model Page site:references name:string

rake db:create
rake db:migrate

cat db/schema.rb
# Confirm that `project_id` is `t.integer` and `site_id` is `t.bigint`.

git add -A
git commit -m "Set up the test condition."

rm ./Gemfile.lock
vim ./Gemfile
# Lock "rails" at "7.0.3".
bundle install
bundle exec rails -v
# Confirm it says "7.0.3"

rake db:drop
rake db:create
rake db:migrate

git diff db/schema.rb
# `project_id` should not have changed, but it has gone from `t.integer` to `t.bigint`.
```

### Expected behavior
I would not expect the 6.0 migrations to start producing changes in `db/schema.rb` when rebuilding it from scratch.

### Actual behavior
I do see changes to `db/schema.rb`:

```diff
--- a/db/schema.rb
+++ b/db/schema.rb
@@ -15,7 +15,7 @@ ActiveRecord::Schema[7.0].define(version: 2022_05_14_034501) do
   enable_extension "plpgsql"
 
   create_table "ideas", force: :cascade do |t|
-    t.integer "project_id", null: false
+    t.bigint "project_id", null: false
     t.string "name"
     t.datetime "created_at", null: false
     t.datetime "updated_at", null: false
```

### System configuration
**Rails version**: `Rails 7.0.3`
**Ruby version**: `ruby 3.0.2p107 (2021-07-07 revision 0db68f0233) [arm64-darwin21]`

title: Normalize `ActiveSupport::Duration` when substracting durations
body:
### Steps to reproduce
<!-- (Guidelines for creating a bug report are [available
here](https://edgeguides.rubyonrails.org/contributing_to_ruby_on_rails.html#creating-a-bug-report)) -->

```ruby
# frozen_string_literal: true

require "bundler/inline"

gemfile(true) do
  source "https://rubygems.org/"
  
  git_source(:github) { |repo| "https://github.com/#{repo}.git" }
  
  # Activate the gem you are reporting the issue against.
  gem "activesupport", "~> 7.0.2.3"
end

require "active_support"
require "active_support/core_ext/numeric/time.rb"
require "minitest/autorun"

class BugTest < Minitest::Test
  def test_stuff
    assert_equal "1 hour and 1 minute", (1.hour + 1.minute).inspect # 
    assert_equal "59 minutes", (1.hour - 1.minute).inspect #  actual: "1 hour and -1 minutes"
  end
end
```

### Expected behavior

```
1 hour and 1 minute
59 minutes
```

### Actual behavior

```
1 hour and 1 minute
1 hour and -1 minutes
```

This can be achieved by passing the result back through a `.build`:

```ruby
p ActiveSupport::Duration.build(1.hour - 1.minute) # => "59 minutes"
```

It would be nice if this was the built-in behavior of subtracting durations. If backwards compatibility or perforance concerns are an issue, then I thing the next-best-thing would be to add a `#normalize` method:

```ruby
p (1.hour - 1.minute).normalize # => "59 minutes"
```

### System configuration

**Rails version**: `rails (7.0.2.3)`
**Ruby version**: `ruby 3.1.2p20`
